label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, May 25, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing a day he spent at the beach swimming and surfing, a beautiful house on a hill they had toured, and advising her on the business affairs of Medway Plantation.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
25 May 1943
Dear Gertrude:
I have the most wonderful sun-burn. The day dawned, a perfect blue
sky, and a brilliant sun topped the mountains, and flooded the Ala Wai
with golden light. It was so lovely in our apartment, with the flowers
that you sent me, and the breeze sweeping through the venetian blinds.
I had hardly finished breakfast, before I went down to the beach, put on
my suit, and took out the surf-board. The waves were breaking high, with
enormous foaming crests a quarter of a mile out; so that it looked as if
we were going to have a magnificent time, on account of the lenght of run
possible. The entire Hawaiian Navy was there. You know, they call the
outrigger canoes and surf-boards, the Hawaiian Navy - which I think is a
lovely name. The boards were so close together that they were absolutely
interlaced, and reminded as of the taxi-cab jams on Forty-second Street
and Broadway. Every time a wave came, we would all start to paddle, after
first giving a loud yell. As the wave swept down on us, and lifted us up,
there was wild confusion. Some people would slide off to the left, and
with of course, the others sliding to the right. Then they would bump,
the boards would fly up in the air, and all you would see was legs and arms,
disappearing into the white foam. After the excitement had quieted down,
and the waves had gone on towards the shore, boards and heads hobbed up
everywhere, and the sea was pin-pointed with black dots. There really
were too many people out to be much fun, as it was dangerous. The inex-
perienced bumping into the experienced, and the experienced ones, thinking
that every one else knew how to surf-board, and therefore going their own
pleasant way; without taking into consideration the fact that others could
not maneuver their boards. Whether we left any dead bodies lying under the
water on the coral, I do not know, but I returned to shore at two c'clock,
bruised and broken.
Morris and I had a delicious luncheon of chicken salad here, on the
sun terrace, over-looking the sea, as we watohed the remaining heroes
still trying to come in on the waves. The meal made me very sleepy
and I was about to lie down to take a nap, when another man suggested that
we go up to see a wonderful house that he knew of. This was the most perfect
house that I have ever seen. The road climbed a hill, turned to the left,
and disgorged into a wide courtyard, surrounded by high walls, covered w ith
Bougainvilla vines. Directly in front, was a garage, which was not really
a garage, but a cave in a wall of rock, that dropped down the mountain-
side. To the right was a narrow stair, tiled with blue tile. It curved
as it mounted, until you arrived at the first story of the house, and
entered through a large glass door. To your amazement you had not entered
the house at all, but were now in a patio, completely surrounded on three
sides by the building; and on the fourth side, by Diamond Head, which
dropped down, forming a straight wall against the back of the house.
All of the bedrooms opened on to this patio, which was aflame with
Bougainvilla, Ginger, and Star Jasmine vines.
[End Page 1]
2.
The rooms all had cork floors, were not very large, but each had attached
to it, an enormous bathroom and dressing room, in which the drawers to
hold the clothes, were made of glass, and were mounted on roller bearings,
so that they slid in and out, noislessly; at the same time, you could see
what was in each drawer, without bothering to open it. Some of the walls
were mosaiced with storks, cherry tree blossoms, etc., and as they were
painted white, it fitted in beautifully. Looking something like
Charley Baskerville's screen. Very airy and light and decorative. While
one side of the bedrooms opened into the patio, the other side opened on
to porches that over-looked the sea. There was an enormous central
living room with a fire-place, and the rest, wide open to the world. Great
windows that slid back and forth, and let the sun pour in, so that the
Chinese yellow carpet on the floor was ablaze with light. As you stepped
out of this room on to the front porch, you saw the most magnificent
picture before you. Away down below, lay the blue sea, stretching out to
the horizon, all aglitter with sunlight. To the right, the curve of
Waikiki Beach disappeared into the palm trees surrounding the Halekulani
Hotel. While to the left, the scimitar of white sand curved slowly until
it met Koko Head. A cascade of Bougainvilla vines fell from the roof
to the porch, and continued in waves down the rock wall until it met the
road, far below. Big leaves, plants, and bushes, rose up from the ground
on the right, and hung over the sides of this porch, forming little
shady spots in which were grouped gay colored chairs, and tiny little
glass-topped tables. A ladder took you up to the top of the house,
which was flat roofed, and here everyone was able to take sun baths.
It is really the most perfect spot I have ever seen. Perhaps some day
we shall be able to live in a place, similar to it.
Y our letter of the 16th. just arrived and I read it with tremendous
pleasure. What interesting dinners you have, and fascinatingpeople at them.
Really you have met the tops, and I assure you that if you join the Waacs
and are a second lieut. you will find that life closed, because for some
reason as soon as you go into an military organization rank seems to be
of great importance, and Field Marshalls just cannot dine with officers of
low rank, although they are delighted to stay with you when a civilian
status is matained. Your picture of the Virginia countryside was so
alluring, the green fields, horses and crops. There is something about
the country that charms me, but pa[s]t experience has taught me the bitter
lesson that acres are aches. The only crops they grow are bushels of
troubles so that ones entire time is taken up with petty details and the
interesting things in life sweep by leaving you in the backwash of fertilizer
combines and sick mules. I would rent the combine to Gippy for $15.00 a
day. Rental to start the moment they take it and to continue until it arrives
back under our shed. This will keep them from leaving it in their fields for
weeks after they have finished using it. They are to do all the transporting
and must return the machine in exactly the same condition it was when they took
it away. In other words they are responsible for all breaks. If they do not want
it on these conditions, leave it where it is. I am tired of being a sucker.
Goodbye darling, I send you all my love and hope that the days are continuhly
growing shorter to that time when I may take you in my arms again.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 2]
